context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: --The Board would be acting beyond its authority if it were an arbitrary effort to effectuate the policies of the act, or if it were inconsistent with the way the Board normally handles these cases and the Board is not announcing a reasoned change in its approach to the cases as a general matter but is just arbitrarily singling someone out.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: That was really what I was trying to get at at the outset by looking at the statute.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: Except for the one prohibition in the statute on ordering backpay or reinstatement of an employee who has been discharged for cause, the question of prophylactic rules is a question left to the Board's discretion in effectuating the policies of the act under the general conferral of authority to--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, given that discretion, is the answer to Justice Stevens' question that yes, the Board could go that far and adopt that strong a rule?

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: --Well, it could, if its rationale were that the rule were needed to effectuate the policies of the act, which do require that the Board hearings be conducted with accurate testimony before it and that can rely on sworn statements and the rest of it, but the Board has taken a more balanced approach.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: There are other purposes of the act to be effectuated as well, and the remedies that it has adopted, just as the remedies that it has adopted in cases of concealment of outside earnings, are balanced so that there is still a disincentive for the employer to engage in unfair labor practices along with a disincentive for the employee to conceal outside earnings, because the employee is denied part of the backpay but the employer still has to pay part of the backpay.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: In the older cases of 1804, where Chief Justice Story referred to the convenience of the parties as being able to be considered, and whether a court would retain jurisdiction in an admiralty salvage case.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: In 1885, in a collision case, an admiralty collision case, the court recognized the discretion of the trial court in weighing the various factors of convenience, of nationality of citizenship in determining whether to retain jurisdiction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What about in England--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Mr. Wagner... Mr. Wagner, the fact that the doctrine may have come up and been applied in some admiralty cases I don't think negates the suggestion from Justice Ginsburg that it was applied across the board.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It was applied in admiralty cases and in other kinds of cases.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: I may not be making myself clear.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: What I'm saying is, the admiralty doctrine has been adopted by several other areas of law, and those other areas of law are free, because they are not constricted, by the uniformity of the general maritime law, to change and apply that doctrine in different fashions, but in admiralty, the Federal courts, and this Court in particular, is the ultimate arbiter of what the uniform rule should be.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I'm not following your argument.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You've already recognized, in response to Justice Scalia's question, that forum non conveniens does not emerge in the common law world for the first time in the context of admiralty, and it is a doctrine that is now applied across the board to cases that were once in equity at law in admiralty, but now you seem to be saying that this doctrine has some special character in admiralty cases that differs it from its shape in other cases.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: I believe that it does, and it has that in two fashions, 1) because it is a part of the uniform admiralty law, which has a precedence, it has a supremacy that common law doesn't necessarily have, and secondly, the admiralty jurisdiction is by its nature extremely broad, extremely vast.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: It touches all sorts of areas of law.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: Your Honor, I... I want its application.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: We request that its application be compulsory, but the doctrine itself, the heart and soul of the doctrine, the issue, the aspect of the doctrine that makes it so valuable, is its discretionary function in the trial judge.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Wagner
context.text: The trial judge is able to weigh the various factors articulated by this Court and determine what is a fair forum for these litigants to try the cases, and the aspect of its discretionary function is why it serves the admiralty, and by that I mean, plaintiffs and defendants.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But Justice Ginsburg's point is that when you have discretion that broad, different trial judges are going to come to different results, widely different results on the basis of the same facts, exactly what discretion is all about.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You can't pretend that you're going to get uniformity of result.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Once you... it's just contradictory to argue that in the interest of uniformity we must have everybody adopt this discretionary doctrine.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-1950, American Dredging Company against Miller will be announced by Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case is here on certiorari from the Supreme Court of Louisiana.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The respondent, William Robert Miller, was injured while working as a seaman board a tug operating on the Delaware River and owned by the petitioner, American Dredging Company, a Pennsylvania Corporation with its principal place of business in New Jersey.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Because forum non conveniens did not originate in admiralty and is a doctrine of general application not limited to admiralty, we think it not a characteristic feature of admiralty law.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Moreover, application of forum non conveniens is not necessary to assure proper uniformity of admiralty law for two reasons: First, it is really a supervening venue rule procedural in nature rather than a substantive rule upon which maritime actors rely in making decisions about how to manage their business affairs; and secondly, it is unlikely to produce uniformed results anyway because the doctrine vests enormous discretion in the Trial Court and encompasses multifarious factors in its application.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Our conclusion is confirmed by prior decisions under the Jones Act and the Federal Employers Liability Act which imply that federal venue rules including forum non conveniens are matters of judicial housekeeping prescribed only for the Federal Courts.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I have an opinion to announce on behalf of Justice O'Connor who is also absent today.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This is No.93-445, Beecham and Jones against the United States.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us on certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Roy B. Woolsey
context.text: It is true that cases do dwell on the circumstances... the Bundles case, the--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, if you're going to... if you're going to construe the statute as implying simply a comparison of values, why do you accept 70 percent?

context.speaker: Roy B. Woolsey
context.text: --Well, I don't know that--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If I lend Justice Scalia 1 and he says I'll give you 70 cents back, I'm going to squawk.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I'm going to say, that's not reasonably equivalent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why are you willing to take 70 percent if you're not willing to lose your 30 percent in view of the circumstances that as a practical matter would prevent you from ever realizing the 30 percent.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But then you are disagreeing even with the Seventh Circuit, with Judge Ripple, who rejected the Ninth Circuit's view but did seem to think the circumstances of the sale, including the foreclosure sale, was a relevant factor.

context.speaker: Roy B. Woolsey
context.text: --I've got to admit that it might be relevant, but how persuasive can it be when the sale price is less than 70 percent?

context.speaker: Roy B. Woolsey
context.text: I think that's my distinction.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In response to Justice Scalia before, you were making the point that unless 458(a)(2) would be meaningless.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that because other provisions of the Bankruptcy Act... not simply State law, but the Bankruptcy Act, will take care of the collusive sale and the sale that does not meet the formalities and the procedures required under State law?

context.speaker: Roy B. Woolsey
context.text: That is certainly true.

context.speaker: Ronald J. Mann
context.text: --Well, for one thing, obviously the statute in California does impose considerably more obligations than that, but I don't think it's clear that Congress intended to have judges attempt to recreate the market and get a better value than the market did, and I guess that's the point I would make on that.

context.speaker: Ronald J. Mann
context.text: One last point I wanted to make about--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What provision... what would the provision be addressed to?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What is your response to the question that Justice Ginsburg asked?

context.speaker: Ronald J. Mann
context.text: --Oh, I... that's a good point.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Taking into account 544, 548(1), what is the independent office of 548(a)(2)?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Justice Scalia has an opinion to announce.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I have the opinion to announce for the Court in No. 92-1370, BFP versus Resolution Trust Corporation.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This case comes to us on certiorari from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: To specify a federal minimum sale price, beyond what state foreclosure law requires, would extend bankruptcy law well beyond the traditional field of fraudulent transfers and upset the coexistence that fraudulent transfer law and foreclosure law have enjoyed for over 400 years.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It is true that under the law of fraudulent transfers, a grossly inadequate price raises a rebuttable presumption of actual fraudulent intent, but it is black letter foreclosure law that when a state's procedures are followed, the mere inadequacy of a foreclosure sale price is no basis for setting aside the sale.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Absent clear or textual guidance than the phrase "reasonably equivalent value", a phrase entirely compatible with preexisting practice, we will not presume that Congress intended to displace traditional state regulation with an interpretation that would profoundly affect the state's essential sovereign interest in the security and stability of title to land.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Souter has filed a dissenting opinion which is joined by Justices Blackmun, Stevens, and Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: Indeed, it appears from the position of the Monroe-Woodbury School District that from the vantage point of the overall school district, this is a preferable accommodation.

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: The Monroe-Woodbury School District did not want to provide teaching at a neutral site in Kiryas Joel.

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: They--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: No, no, no, my question, following Justice O'Connor's, was, had Aguilar v. Felton come out the other way--

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --And these services had been provided in the private schools themselves, would you then nevertheless have had the constitutional option to have the district formed as it was here?

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: --With all respect, Justice O'Connor, I think the Sabbatarian case was one in which this Court felt that there was a burden on others to pick up for the Sabbatarian, and in that footnote in which Justice Brennan in his Texas Monthly case speaks of accommodations, he refers to the fact that that's a distinction, whether the nonobservers are burdened by the statute.

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: In this case, there's no burden on anyone else.

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: This is simply a statute which applies to this municipality and essentially what the courts below have said is that these people, because they are religious, cannot be trusted to run a public school system.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Lewin, I took you a moment ago in your answer to Justice Kennedy's question about the significance of Aguilar to accept the proposition that in judging what is a permissible, permissive accommodation, that the range of possible alternatives for the accommodation should be considered.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that... do you think that's a... basically a fair premise?

context.speaker: Nathan Lewin
context.text: Well, the need for accommodation, I don't think the range of accommodations.

context.speaker: Jay Worona
context.text: --Well, I think the purpose certainly here is one of segregation along religious lines.

context.speaker: Jay Worona
context.text: It was the pursuit of that particular principle that was primarily sought after, and indeed was advanced by this legislation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The... aren't you giving two different answers?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, you're giving a purpose answer to Justice Kennedy, and a moment ago you gave a no alternative answer to me when we were discussing the problem posed by the Chief's hypothetical on the Roman Catholics.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is the problem, as you see it, that there was an express purpose to transfer power to a religious group, or is the problem here that there were alternatives to doing that, to accomplish the same result, and they didn't avail themselves of the alternatives?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Which is it?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It provides no means by which another religious group or a non-sectarian group might obtain the same benefit, nor does the historically practice in the state give any indication that other applicants for small separate district would be treated as the Satmars were.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Our history, in fact, suggests that they would not be.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: While the State of New York may do a number of things to address the educational problems of handicap children in Kiryas Joel, it may not provide this kind of special treatment.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: A separate portion of my opinion joined by Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Justice Ginsburg explains the state's further problem of delegating political power to a group defined according to religion.

context.text: The New York legislature purposely drew the school district in a way that made it all Satmar so that the Satmar community could effectively control public schools in its neighborhood.

context.text: The Establishment Clause forbids a state to confer a civil authority on a group identified by law according to its religion.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: It does not allow the admission of the entire confession just because some parts of it are against the declarant's interest or because the confession, seen as a whole, is against the declarant's interest.

context.text: Because at least some of what Harris said really did not implicate Harris himself, but only implicated Williamson, we conclude that those statements should not have been admitted.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We remand the case to the Court of Appeals to apply these principles in the first instance.
